citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection the following animals were identified as needing veterinary care:
-One turkey tom had significant feather loss on his back, wings, and chest.
-In pen #5, there was one adult black hen with significant feather loss to the neck and chest.
-In pen #9, there were two adult black hens with significant feather loss on back, wings, and neck.
-In pen #13, there was one adult brown and cream hen with significant feather loss on upper wings and back
-In pen #17, there were two multi-colored hens with significant feather loss on lower back.
Lack of daily observations and communication with the attending veterinarian can result in worsening of the conditions.
Feather loss can be caused by many factors including: an aggressive rooster, overbreeding, molting, mites, parasites,
bacteria or fungal infections, poor nutrition, stress, boredom, bullying, and feather puling. Open red exposed skin can lead
to more aggression from other birds in the enclosure, resulting in injuries and death. Birds that appear sick can be due to
a variety of health conditions that require consultation with the veterinarian for accurate diagnosis and treatment.
The licensee must complete daily observations to assess health and well-being of the animals and facilitate direct and
frequent communication with the attending veterinarian to allow for timely and accurate information to be conveyed to the
attending veterinarian on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being. Correct by: close of business Monday,
June 24, 2024.

The water receptacle in the primary enclosure for 15 ducks was not being filled on a daily basis. There was evidence of
rust in the trough part. The pond in the primary enclosure had a dark green algae build-up.
Failure to provide fresh, potable water, and keep receptacles clean can result in illness and death. Potable water must be
provided in sufficient quantity to all birds housed at the facility. Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitized in
accordance with section 3.158, as often as necessary to prevent contamination. The licensee must provide potable water
to all birds, keep water receptacles clean and sanitary to protect the health of the birds. Potable water was provided at
time of the inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Kira Wagner, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
